abstract.p: An autonomous and secure navigation system is needed for the spacecraft in future deep space missions. X-ray pulsar offers the possibility of autonomous navigation anywhere in the solar system. This article introduces an analysis of the spacecraft autonomous navigation system accuracy, utilizing signals emitted from the X-ray pulsars. Based on the principle of the X-ray navigation, visibility of X-ray pulsar on L1 sun-observation orbit was simulated. The influence of the geometry distribution and the pulsar angle position error was analyzed. Error sources of the navigation system were listed, including the measurement error of the X-ray detector, transformation error of time-of-arrival (TOA), and the navigation calculation error, and the simulations of their parts were shown.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Currently, most space vehicle operations rely heavily on Earth-based navigation solutions to complete their tasks.1 Several researchers have shown that the navigation solution for aerial and low-Earth orbit application can be obtained by utilizing global positioning system (GPS). On the other hand, the deep space network (DSN) has been used for deep space missions.2 GPS can provide a complete navigation solution consisted of referenced time, position, velocity, altitude, and altitude rate. However, these satellite systems have limited scope for operation of vehicles relatively far away from the Earth. DSN assists navigation of vehicles distant from the Earth by determining range and range rate along the line of sight from the ground radar station to the vehicle. But accuracy is reduced for the two transverse axes of position, and DSN requires extensive ground operations and scheduling. To improve the safety and reliability of the spacecraft, especially to draw rein, many countries with space-flight programs show great interest in the investigation of autonomous navigation problems.3 In order to reduce the dependence of navigation systems to ground-based operations and achieve more autonomy, the utilization of celestial-based navigation systems is desirable. Such systems use signals emitted from celestial sources that are located at great distances from the Earth. Due to their special characteristics, X-ray pulsars are potential candidates for use in navigation systems.2

The concept of utilizing pulsars for spacecraft navigation has been in development since the discovery of the rapidly rotating neutron stars in the 1960s.4 The Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) conducted studies in the 1970s and 1980s, proposing the use of the pulsar signals as navigation beacons in both the radio and the X-ray bands of the electromagnetic spectrum.5 Since the 1980s, the Naval Research Laboratory (NRL) has studied the X-ray sources and developed detectors, providing the foundations for the X-ray source spacecraft navigation development. Several important dissertation researches were pursued in the 1990s and 2000s. During the last several years, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) and National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) have supported more in-depth development focused on the preparation of an operating instrument for an eventual space-flight demonstration.6

Hanson7 presents the principles of the X-ray navigation using the X-ray source to determine the spacecraft altitude and time. Sala et al.8 present the feasibility study for a spacecraft navigation system relying on the pulsar timing information. Sheikh9 in his doctoral dissertation, “The use of the variable celestial X-ray sources for spacecraft navigation”, describes spacecraft autonomous navigation based on the X-ray sources and proposes a variety of methods for positioning, altitude, and timing determination. Hanson et al.10 analyze the noise and modeling of the X-ray pulsar navigation. Graven et al.6 describe the use of the X-ray pulsar navigation in deep space exploration process and the error estimation principle. Emadzadeh and Speyer2 present a new relative navigation system based on the X-ray pulsar measurements. Currently, there are only a few articles that explain the accuracy analysis of the spacecraft navigation based on the X-ray pulsars.

This article is divided into four major sections that include the principle of pulsar navigation; the visibility of the X-ray pulsar and the influence of the geometry distribution and the pulsar angle position; the measurement error of the X-ray detector, transformation error of time-of-arrival (TOA), and the navigation calculation error; and finally concluding remarks.

In particular, this article based on the engineering application presents the X-ray pulsar signal quality evaluation, visibility, geometric distribution, ephemeris errors, and detector measurement error and analyzes the influencing factors of the engineering applications of the X-ray pulsars’ autonomous navigation. The technical foundation is provided for the autonomous navigation of spacecraft engineering applications based on the X-ray pulsars.

sec.title: Principle of the X-ray navigation and error analyzing
sec.p: The principle of the X-ray detector-based spacecraft navigation is that the position and velocity of spacecraft are calculated on the photon information from the X-ray pulsar. The process of navigation is described in Figure 1 and is divided into three steps. First, the arrival time of photon is recorded while the photon is detected by the X-ray detector. Second, the arrival time of impulse is calculated using the following steps: producing an observation profile using epoch folding, comparing that to the standard profile that is stored in the ephemeris, and calculating the time arrival of pulse; finally, the Kalman filter is adopted to calculate the high-precision orbit and time information of the spacecraft. The arrival time of impulse is the measurement value, and the orbit dynamic expression is the state equation while designing the Kalman filter. It is easy to know that the errors exist in each step of navigation process. The sources of errors mainly include measure errors of detector, calculate errors of TOA, and calculate errors of navigation algorithm. In addition, the visibility of the X-ray pulsar is the primal condition of the X-ray-based navigation; thus, the analysis on the visibility and distribution of the X-ray pulsar in various orbits should be carried out first.

sec.title: Geometry distribution of the pulsar
sec.p: For the reason that the distance between the pulsar stars and the solar system is about 1019 m, the radiation generated by the pulsars is approximately parallel with respect to the spacecraft traveling through the solar system. The configurations of the pulsars are fixed and do not vary with the height of the orbit, as well as the position at the same height. Therefore, this article introduces geometric dilution of precision (GDOP) to explain the influence of the pulsars’ geometric configurations on the navigation precision.

GDOP is combined with ephemeris information, the pulsar position estimation, and the time accuracy. It is difficult to obtain better position solution when the directions of the navigation pulsars are similar to each other. sec.title: Influence of the pulsar angle position error on navigation precision
sec.p: The angle position of the pulsars is described by longitude λ and latitude α with respect to the sun inertia frame, and then the reference vector of the pulsar with respect to the sun inertia frame is given by n=[cosαcosλcosαsinλsinα], which is the direction reference of the determination of the spacecraft orbit and altitude. Therefore, the error of the angle position will lead to the error of the observation matrix H and the bias of the time change. When the error of pulsar angle position is 10 mas, the bias of the time change is generally 10 µs.13 At present, the angle precision of most pulsars has reached 10 ms order. Furthermore, the longitude λ and latitude α change gradually, and the phenomenon is usually called the proper motion of pulsars. Thus, the parameter error of proper motion should be taken into consideration when we analyze the error source of the time change. For the time being, the least angle position error among all pulsars known is PSR B1937+21, and the error of the longitude and latitude is 0.012 and 0.14mas, respectively.

sec.title: Analysis on accuracy of the X-ray pulsar navigation system
Measurement error of the X-ray pulsar detector
sec.p: Response time and time benchmark error are the main parts that lead to the measurement error of the X-ray pulsar detector. When the X-ray pulsar detector receives the X-ray photons, it cannot response immediately, and it needs some response time, so it results in time delay. Taking swept charge device (SCD) X-ray pulsar detector to observe Crab pulsars as an example, the temporal resolution is 1 ms.14 The true profile and response profile are shown in Figure 6. The results show that response profile is different from the true profile, and response profile has phase delay compared with the true profile. The response time is 0.69 ms.

caption.p: Response time curve of SCD detector.

sec.p: Time benchmark error is another error of the X-ray pulsar detector besides response time error. The 1PPS of the GPS receiver is generally used as time benchmark by spacecraft. The time error is 50 nm. The response time error belongs to the system error. It can be compensated and ground calibrated.

sec.title: Transformation error of TOA
sec.p: The performance of the X-ray pulsar navigation mostly depends on the TOA accuracy. The variance of TOA is estimated by the following two methods: estimation based on signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and estimation based on profile function of pulsar. In order to show the effect of TOA to navigation accuracy, let us use, for example, the estimation based on SNR.

Estimation based on SNR is to directly estimate measurement accuracy of TOA by SNR with the known parameter, such as pulsar flux. sec.p: The above-mentioned figures show that the larger the sensitive detection area, the higher the pulsar navigation precision, and the longer the integration time, the lesser the measurement error. But if the integration time is too long, it leads to much larger navigation error. State variables of spacecraft can be obtained by the system state equations during the integration time of pulsar signal. The precision of estimated state variables will decrease as the integration time increases. Filter divergence may occur if the integration time is too long. Therefore, in the practical application, we choose the appropriate integration time taking into account instrument noise, filter algorithm, and onboard computer.

sec.p: Navigation calculation accuracy error includes the state equation error, the measurement equation error, and the filtering error. The state equation depends on the spacecraft orbit. sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Based on the principle of the X-ray navigation, the visibility of the X-ray pulsar on L1 sun-observation orbit was simulated. The influence of the geometry distribution and the pulsar angle position error was analyzed. Error sources of the navigation system were listed, including the measurement error of the X-ray detector, transformation error of TOA, and the navigation calculation error, and the simulations of their parts were shown. The X-ray pulsar as a unique source provides pulsed radiation that can be utilized in autonomous navigation system for spacecraft. Given their vast distances from the Earth, the pulsars provide good signal coverage for operations to the moon, mars, throughout the solar system, and, conceivably, galaxy.
